item.title: Brigitte Bardot: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The movies made the French actress a star, but photography sealed her stardom.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: From Sex Appeal to the Far Right, Brigitte Bardot Symbolized a Changing France
item.description: In the decades after becoming a megastar, the French actress became as known for her politics as she once had been for her acting career.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Herbert Dorfman/Corbis, via Getty Images

item.title: Want to Build a Better World? The São Paulo Bienal Has Some Tips
item.description: “Not All Travelers Walk Roads,” the 36th edition of the exhibition, sees art as a guide for connecting with each other and with the earth.
item.dc:creator: Aruna D’Souza

item.title: 8 Ways A.I. Affected Pop Culture in 2025
item.description: No longer something off in the distance, the new technology was all over our screens this past year.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams

item.title: Park Chan-wook and the Funny Thing About Stomach-Churning Horror
item.description: When American studios wouldn’t back his film about a laid-off manager committing gruesome murders, the director returned to Korea. Now he has a hit on his hands.
item.dc:creator: Robert Ito
item.media:credit: Maggie Shannon for The New York Times
item.media:description: When Park adds humor to his films, “it sometimes skips a couple of steps, so it can go over people’s heads,” Lee said.

item.title: Marcello Hernández Can Handle the Haters
item.description: He once thought his comedy career was over before it even began. Now he’s an “S.N.L.” star with a Netflix special coming in January.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff and OK McCausland
item.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times

item.title: Lucien Laviscount on His ‘Emily in Paris’ Game
item.description: “You get to see a bit more of someone than they’d probably like to let you see,” said the actor, who plays Emily’s ex Alfie on the Netflix series.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Pascal Le Segretain/Getty Images

item.title: The Nazi Plunder of Church Bells Changed the Sound of Europe
item.description: As church bells chime and peal the New Year, historians say the looting of more than 150,000 bells during World War II left “a sonic gap” in the landscape.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal and Desiré Van Den Berg
item.media:description: A bell inside the Dom Tower in Utrecht, the Netherlands. Thousands of Dutch church bells were destroyed by the Nazis, melted down for weapons and ammunition. A few of the oldest were protected as monuments, marked with an “M.”

item.title: The Berlin Apartment
item.description: The Berlin Apartment, which owes a debt to What Remains of Edith Finch, lets you relive the challenges its many tenants faced.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Byrd

item.title: 43 Fun Things to Do on New Year’s Eve in N.Y.C.
item.description: What are you doing to greet 2026? Our suggestions include fancy parties, all-night dance-a-thons, choose-your-own movie double features and a pasta-making class.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg
item.category: Cathedral Church of St John the Divine (Manhattan, NY)
item.media:credit: Brendan McDermid/Reuters
item.media:description: The new Constellation Ball, which will make its inaugural drop in Times Square to ring in the new year.

item.title: 9 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Timothée Chalamet in “Marty Supreme,” set in 1952 New York and directed by Josh Safdie with electrifying flourish.

item.title: From ‘Splitsville’ to ‘Friendship,’ the Year’s Best Fight Scenes
item.description: Everywhere you looked this year, men were feuding. In movies like “Splitsville,” “Eddington” and “Friendship,” it was gloriously pathetic.
item.dc:creator: Max Cea

item.title: Did We Underestimate Kate Hudson?
item.description: For years she was pigeonholed as a rom-com star. Her turn as a blue-collar mom with a love of Neil Diamond just might vault her back to the Oscars.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Thea Traff

item.title: 64 Visuals That Defined the Year in Arts
item.description: Bad Bunny, Addison Rae, Audra McDonald, a cotillion class, Bing the dog and many more were subjects of the photographs commissioned by our photo editors this year.
item.dc:creator: Maridelis Morales Rosado, Laura O’Neill, Jolie Ruben and Amanda Webster
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: New Year’s Eve Specials, Plus 4 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: CNN, CBS and ABC ring in 2026, and a new reality show set in Palm Beach begins.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:credit: Adrienne Grunwald for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left: Andy Cohen and Anderson Cooper during the 2024 CNN New Year’s Eve special.

item.title: Five Brigitte Bardot Movies to Stream
item.description: The actress, who died at 91, had what can’t be taught: charisma and attitude onscreen. Here are some highlights.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: Vienna’s Ball Season Traditions of Waltzes and White Ties
item.description: The annual Vienna Philharmonic Ball anchors a winter calendar of some 450 dances across the city that open a window into Viennese tradition, then and now.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Schmid

item.title: A Star Conductor Brings Sparkle to Vienna’s New Year’s Concert
item.description: For the first time, Yannick Nézet-Séguin will lead the Vienna Philharmonic’s most-watched event of the year: its annual concert on New Year’s Day.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.media:credit: Rob Cardillo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yannick Nézet-Séguin is the music director of the Metropolitan Opera and the Philadelphia Orchestra, and artistic director of the Orchestre Métropolitain in Montreal.

item.title: Vienna to Stage Gender-Bending, Jazz Age Comedy Once Banned by Franco
item.description: MusikTheater an der Wien will stage Pablo Luna’s “Benamor,” a rarely seen example of the Spanish zarzuela genre from the Roaring Twenties in Madrid.
item.dc:creator: David Belcher
item.media:credit: Florentina Olareanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Oller left, as Juan de León, and Federico Fiorio as Darío in “Benamor,” which will be performed at the MusikTheater an der Wien starting next month.

item.title: Brigitte Bardot, French Movie Icon Who Renounced Stardom, Dies at 91
item.description: “And God Created Woman” made her a world-famous sex symbol in the 1950s. She later gave up acting to devote her life to animal welfare.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates
item.media:credit: Robert Walker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Brigitte Bardot in 1965, when she was at the height of her movie stardom. She was at the Plaza Hotel in New York promoting the western comedy “Viva Maria!” for which she received her only acting-award nomination, in Britain.

item.title: The Artists Behind “Exactitudes" Capture How People Use Clothes to Create Identity
item.description: Two artists spent 30 years cataloging how people dress and learned a lot about humanity in the process.
item.dc:creator: Stella Bugbee

item.title: Gary Graffman, Piano Virtuoso and Renowned Teacher, Dies at 97
item.description: Mr. Graffman was a onetime child prodigy whose career was curtailed by a neurological condition that restricted him to his left hand.
item.dc:creator: Vivien Schweitzer
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gary Graffman in 2018, when he turned 90. He was an acclaimed concert pianist before developing focal dystonia, the neurological disorder that restricted him to his left hand, in his 50s.

item.title: Mickey Lee, a ‘Big Brother’ Contestant, Dies at 35
item.description: Ms. Lee, a party host in Atlanta, died from multiple cardiac arrests brought on by the flu, according to a social media post.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Paras Griffin/Getty Images
item.media:description: Mickey Lee, an event curator in Atlanta, competed in the latest season of “Big Brother” on CBS.

item.title: A Second Lawsuit Accuses Tyler Perry of Sexual Assault
item.description: Mario Rodriguez, who had a role in one of Mr. Perry’s films, sued him on Thursday, months after another actor filed a similar lawsuit.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado and Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Mario Anzuoni/Reuters
item.media:description: The actor and director Tyler Perry was named as a defendant in a sexual harassment lawsuit filed on Thursday in California.

item.title: How ‘Marty Supreme’ Got Ping Pong Right
item.description: The director Josh Safdie had a personal connection to 1950s players, but he also enlisted professionals to choreograph the action and employed a visual trick.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: For a Night at the Museum, Pajamas and Dinosaurs
item.description: Roaming the American Museum of Natural History in pajamas made for a night to remember for hundreds of children and their brave parents.
item.dc:creator: Vidhya Nagarajan and Sarah Bahr

item.title: 7 Book Podcasts to Indulge, Develop or Rekindle a Love of Reading
item.description: In a world filled with digital distractions, these shows will help you indulge, develop or rekindle a love for reading.
item.dc:creator: Emma Dibdin
item.category: What Should I Read Next? (Radio Program)

item.title: How Anthony Ramos, a ‘Hamilton’ Star, Spends a Day at His Brooklyn Bar
item.description: Anthony Ramos loves hanging out with customers during busy days that may find him writing a new musical, catching a friend in a show or performing in his own.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Ahmed Gaber
item.media:description: Anthony Ramos, left, is a Brooklyn-born actor who starred as John Laurens and Philip Hamilton in the original Broadway cast of Lin-Manuel Miranda’s “Hamilton.”

item.title: Perry Bamonte, Guitarist and Keyboardist in the Cure, Dies at 65
item.description: A former roadie, Mr. Bamonte joined the band in 1990. He played on five albums and in hundreds of shows and was “a vital part of the Cure story,” the band said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Tim Mosenfelder/Getty Images
item.media:description: Perry Bamonte of the Cure performing at the Shoreline Amphitheatre in 2000 in Mountain View, Calif.

item.title: Michal Urbaniak, Pioneering Jazz Fusion Violinist, Dies at 82
item.description: One of the first jazz musicians from Poland to gain an international following, he recorded more than 60 albums and played with stars like Miles Davis.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:credit: Tamasz Gzell/PAP, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Mr. Urbaniak performing in Warsaw in 2010. He had forged his career in New York City — “the only home for a jazzman,” he said.

item.title: The 40 Best New York Times Illustrations of 2025
item.description: The most memorable illustrations of the year, chosen by art directors at The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include a World War I revenge tale, a vampire superhero and female assassins.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels
item.category: The Old Woman With The Knife (Movie)

item.title: 5 Comedy Specials to Get You Through the Holidays
item.description: For very different reasons, new hours from Dave Chappelle, Kevin Hart, Kathleen Madigan, George Civeris and Jay Jurden are worth your time.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: How a Deadly Bond Develops in ‘Avatar: Fire and Ash’
item.description: James Cameron narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Oona Chaplin and Stephen Lang.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: A Behind-the-Scenes Player of a Transformed Broadway Takes a Bow
item.description: The nonprofit organization New 42, which earned a Tony Honor for Excellence in the Theater this year, continues to pave the way for a revitalized Times Square.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Graeber
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New Victory Theater celebrated its 30th anniversary this year with a big party.

item.title: The Defining Culture Visuals of 2025
item.description: Three photo editors from the Culture desk share their favorite images from 2025.
item.dc:creator: Jolie Ruben, Amanda Webster, Maridelis Morales Rosado, Gabby Bulgarelli, Sutton Raphael, Lauren Pruitt and Luke Piotrowski

item.title: All the Cameos in ‘Marty Supreme,’ From Kevin O’Leary to Tyler, the Creator
item.description: A “Shark Tank” investor, a supermarket magnate and even N.B.A. All-Stars make appearances in the table tennis comedy.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: ‘Avatar: Fire and Ash' | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: James Cameron narrates a sequence from his film.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: John Carey, Literary Eminence Who Excoriated Snobbery, Dies at 91
item.description: An Oxford professor and renowned critic, he was pugnacious, fearless and disdainful of the received wisdom of his intellectual milieu.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Robert Lindsey, Times Reporter and Reagan Ghostwriter, Dies at 90
item.description: The nonfiction spy thriller “The Falcon and the Snowman,” which became a film, grew out of his work as a journalist covering the West Coast for The Times.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert Lindsey in 1979, when he was the Los Angeles bureau chief for The New York Times.

item.title: ‘No Other Choice’ Review: A Company Man Cut Loose
item.description: Park Chan-wook, the director of “Oldboy” and “The Handmaiden,” brings comedic flair to the cruel tale of an employee pushed to the brink.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Turn On, Tune In … Cop Out? ‘Sixties Surreal’ Teases at the Whitney.
item.description: A spotty but thrilling tour of American art from Eisenhower to Nixon shows just how unhinged the ’60s were, and how hard it is to summarize the era.
item.dc:creator: Walker Mimms and Janice Chung
item.media:description: Paul Thek’s grotesque assemblage from the series “Technological Reliquaries,” 1966, at “Sixties Surreal” at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Inside a glittery Plexiglas case, drawing from relics of the saints, he created a real-looking limb that seems to ooze a marrow-like substance, a response to the carnage of the Vietnam War.

item.title: 9 Art Shows to See Before They Close This Winter
item.description: Catch a lush Monet blockbuster, gorgeous Egyptian goddesses and the history of Black Broadway before they’re gone.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Sherman
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the “Sixties Surreal” exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art, there are works by more than 100 artists on display.

item.title: K-Pop in 2025: What ‘KPop Demon Hunters’ and NewJeans Tell Us About the Genre
item.description: The genre peaked in terms of global awareness with “KPop Demon Hunters,” while the industry’s most promising new act was mired in a legal morass.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Danielle from NewJeans onstage in Hong Kong in March. The group had hoped to kick off a new era with a fresh start, but remains in its old recording contract.

item.title: Phyllis Lee Levin, Times Fashion Reporter and Biographer, Dies at 104
item.description: Her 1960 essay about the frustrations of educated women prefigured Betty Friedan’s “The Feminine Mystique.” She later wrote books on John Quincy Adams and others.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: The Remarkable Education of John Quincy Adams (Book)

item.title: ‘Marty Supreme’ Review: Timothée Chalamet Sprints to the Top
item.description: The actor stars as a magnetic, striving table-tennis champ in Josh Safdie’s new movie, one of the most exciting movies of the year.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.media:description: Timothée Chalamet in “Marty Supreme,” set in 1952 New York and directed by Josh Safdie with electrifying flourish.

item.title: The Ping-Pong Hustler Who Inspired ‘Marty Supreme’
item.description: Volleying questions with the table tennis champ Marty Reisman, an inspiration for Timothée Chalamet’s new film, showed that he was a character in his own right.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Donald F. Holway/The New York Times
item.media:description: Marty Reisman won 22 major table tennis titles over the course of a colorful career.

item.title: ‘Tartuffe’ Gets a Colorfully Modern Makeover
item.description: With its profanity-laced script, Lucas Hnath’s Molière adaptation, starring Matthew Broderick, is a mischievous clash of the old and the new.
item.dc:creator: Tim Teeman
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from above left: Matthew Broderick, Amber Gray and David Cross, below, in “Tartuffe” at New York Theater Workshop.

item.title: ‘The Testament of Ann Lee’ Review: A Woman Clothed With the Sun
item.description: In an extraordinary performance, Amanda Seyfried plays the founder of the Shakers in a singular film.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘The Choral’ Review: Singing to Keep the Fear at Bay
item.description: As England goes to war, a provincial choir master played by Ralph Fiennes is challenged to find available voices in this poignant drama set in 1916.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: ‘Song Sung Blue’ Review: A Christmas ‘Caroline’
item.description: Craig Brewer’s toe-tapping weepie about the triumphs and tragedies of a Neil Diamond tribute band is exactly the movie we need right now.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘The Plague’ Review: Pool of the Flies
item.description: A stunner of a debut film follows a group of boys at a water polo camp, where an outsider is just trying to fit in.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Anaconda’ Review: Back in the Jungle
item.description: The movie gets at least one thing right: Rebooting the shlocky, widely-panned creature-feature, starring Jack Black and Paul Rudd, is a goofy idea.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: ‘Father Mother Sister Brother’ Review: Families, Untied
item.description: Jim Jarmusch’s uneven triptych, a prizewinner at Venice, saves its best segment for last.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Modern Love Podcast’: Andrew Garfield Wants to Crack Open Your Heart
item.description: The actor knows life is fleeting, but he wants to hold on to every moment.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Amy Pearl, Sara Curtis, Elisa Gutierrez, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Aman Sahota and Diane Wong
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Greg Allen/Invision, via Associated Press

item.title: ‘Goodbye June’ Review: Terms of Endearment, and Estrangement
item.description: Kate Winslet directs a formulaic script by her son, Joe Anders, about a dying matriarch and her quarreling adult children.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: ‘Stranger Things’ Creators Break Down Their Latest Influences
item.description: With a new batch of episodes arriving on Christmas Day, Matt and Ross Duffer discuss the sometimes obscure movie and video game references in the final season so far.
item.dc:creator: Austin Considine

item.title: An Ecological Tale Gives Life to Metroid Prime 4
item.description: A slow start is overcome while learning about an extinct alien race that welcomed a savior.
item.dc:creator: Harold Goldberg

item.title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs’s Lawyers File Appeal, Arguing His Sentence Was Unjust
item.description: The mogul’s lawyers say that a judge issued an excessively steep sentence for prostitution offenses after Mr. Combs was acquitted of more serious charges.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs and Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Mark Von Holden/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sean Combs was convicted of arranging for the travel of male escorts across state lines but acquitted of sex trafficking and racketeering conspiracy.

item.title: Robert Nakamura, ‘Godfather’ of Asian American Film, Dies at 88
item.description: In his work, he often returned to Manzanar, the camp in which he and his family, along with thousands of other people of Japanese descent, were interned during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

item.title: 10 Songs That Explain My Year
item.description: From Gustav Mahler to Lady Gaga, a peek into Lindsay’s past 12 months in music.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Nicholas Albrecht for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tracy Chapman

item.title: British Police Drop Case Against Bob Vylan After Its Anti-Israel Chant
item.description: Bob Vylan, a punk-rap duo, caused international outrage by chanting the message at the Glastonbury music festival this year.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Glastonbury Festival of Contemporary Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jewish groups, as well as Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, had condemned the chant as hate speech.

item.title: Russell Brand Is Charged With Additional Counts of Rape and Sexual Assault
item.description: The actor, comedian and YouTuber now faces seven counts of rape and sexual assault in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Reuters
item.media:description: Russell Brand at a London courthouse in May.
